				<div id="main-content">
		<div class="container">
		<div id="content-area" class="clearfix">
			<div class="et_pb_extra_column_main">
																<article id="post-96335" class="module single-post-module post-96335 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-news et-has-post-format-content et_post_format-et-post-format-standard">
														<div class="post-header">
								<h1 class="entry-title">Woke NFL adds National Coming Out Day to its social justice agenda</h1>
								<div class="post-meta vcard">
									<p><a class="url fn" title="Canadian Press" rel="author">Canadian Press</a> | <span class="updated">Oct 16, 2020</span> | <a href="https://www.gopusa.com/category/news/" rel="tag">News</a> | <a class="comments-link" href="https://www.gopusa.com/woke-nfl-adds-national-coming-out-day-to-its-social-justice-agenda/#comments">66 <span title="comment count" class="comment-bubble post-meta-icon"></span></a></p>
								</div>
							</div>
							
														<div class="post-thumbnail header">
								<img src="https://www.gopusa.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/nfl_pride.jpg" alt="Woke NFL adds National Coming Out Day to its social justice agenda" /><p class="caption">Did the NFL miss alienating a few fans?  They're going to fix that right now!</p>							</div>
							
														
							<div class="post-wrap">
															<div class="post-content entry-content">
									<p>NEW YORK — The NFL has launched a series of initiatives associated with LGBTQ History Month, which includes National Coming Out Day on Sunday and Spirit Day on Thursday.</p>
<p>Included are a dedicated website (NFL.com/PRIDE ); a PSA celebrating former NFL players who have come out voicing support; expanded partnerships with GLAAD and The Trevor Project; a pride-themed NFL shield; and an assortment of LGBTQ content airing on NFL Network throughout October.</p>
<p>“The LGBTQ community is an important audience for our sport and a critical part of the NFL family,” said Jonathan Beane, the NFL&#8217;s chief diversity officer. “We continually strive to provide an inclusive and welcoming environment for all.”</p>
<p><iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/XoTylSXO6iU" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe></p>
<p>The PSA that will debut Sunday will feature former NFL players Wade Davis, Ryan O&#8217;Callaghan, Ryan Russell and Jeff Rohrer. Current players Anthony Barr, Calais Campbell, Rob Gronkowski, Anthony Harris, Marlon Humphrey, DeAndre Hopkins, Jarvis Landry and Dalton Risner will offer their support for the LGBTQ community.</p>
<p>In an NFL.com op-ed, Troy Vincent, who overseas league football operations, discusses his commitment to fostering a welcoming and safe environment to active NFL players who are contemplating coming out.</p>
<p>On Thursday, the NFL will join the pledge to “go purple” to support LGBTQ youth in a united stand against bullying.</p>
<p>NFL PRIDE is an employee resource group that aims to heighten the visibility and celebrate members of the LGBTQ community across NFL offices and teams so that employees of all gender identities and sexual orientations can feel comfortable in the workplace. It also helps provide perspective and advises on league initiatives relating to the LGBTQ community and helps administer an advisory working group consisting of players, staff and advocacy partners.</p>
<p>___</p>
<p>More AP NFL coverage: https://apnews.com/NFL and https://twitter.com/AP_NFL</p>
<p>© 2020 The Canadian Press. All rights reserved.</p>
<p>&#8212;-</p>

				<p>&#8220;“The LGBTQ community is an important audience for our sport and a critical part of the NFL family,”&#8221;</p>
<p><strong>The NFL officially has turn its back on GOD&#8217;s word, Christians, Jews, Muslims and all those who condemn the LGBTQ lifestyle.</strong></p>
<p>I will never watch or support in any way the NFL or the NBA.<br />
 I choose to follow GOD and his son Jesus Christ and NOT the lies of the evil one and his disciples.</p>
<p>One&#8217;s relationship with GOD is entirely between them and GOD.</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-oldsarge even thread-even depth-1" id="li-comment-414794">
		<article id="comment-414794" class="comment-body clearfix">
			<div class="comment_avatar">
					<img src="https://www.gopusa.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/avatar-default-bubble2-150x150.png" width="80" height="80" alt="Avatar" class="avatar avatar-80wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-80 alignnone photo avatar-default" />			</div>

			<div class="comment_postinfo">
					<span class="fn">oldsarge</span>				<span class="comment_date">
					on 9:55 am October 16, 2020 at 9:55 am				</span>
												</div> <!-- .comment_postinfo -->

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>It&#8217;s all politics.  Professional and amateur sports is being ruined by political correctness.  I don&#8217;t even care who wins.  Politics does not belong in professional or amateur sporting events.  I am not amused by these shameless grandstanding prime-donas.  If they want to make a political statement, I am sure the media would gladly give them air time on their networks. </p>
<p>I haven&#8217;t gone to a professional or college game in years.  If I want to watch them, I prefer to do it in the comforts of my home.  At home I can turn them off or not turn them on at all.  At home, I don&#8217;t have to pay those outrageous prices for tickets along with the outrageous cost of hot dogs, popcorn and drinks.</p>

<div class="gdrts-rating-block gdrts-align-none gdrts-method-stars-rating gdrts-block-stars-rating-item-414479 gdrts-rating-allowed gdrts-rating-open  gdrts-item-entity-comments gdrts-item-name-comment gdrts-item-id-414794 gdrts-item-itemid-414479">
    <div class="gdrts-inner-wrapper">

            <div class="gdrts-rating-text">
                Rating: <strong>5.0</strong>/5. From 16 votes.            </div>

				<p>As long as you don&#8217;t go to the channel you will not be counted.  I know a lot of my friends are having ESPN removed from their service.  I can&#8217;t do that with my provider. I just have to be careful and make sure I don&#8217;t link up with the sports stations.  As I said, I can turn them off or not turn them on at all.  I chose not to turn them on at all.</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-jimbo999 even depth-2" id="li-comment-415045">
		<article id="comment-415045" class="comment-body clearfix">
			<div class="comment_avatar">
					<img src="https://www.gopusa.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/avatar-default-bubble2-150x150.png" width="80" height="80" alt="Avatar" class="avatar avatar-80wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-80 alignnone photo avatar-default" />			</div>

			<div class="comment_postinfo">
					<span class="fn">jimbo999</span>				<span class="comment_date">
					on 3:19 pm October 17, 2020 at 3:19 pm				</span>
												</div> <!-- .comment_postinfo -->

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>Unfortunately you do pay for the games when you buy something from one or more of their advertisers.  Just think about it when you buy a bottle of flavored water form Coke or Pepsi.  They pay a couple of cents for the can, and a couple of cents for the flavoring and sugar.  The rest of the outrageous cost you paid goes to the TV stations and networks, the sports teams and leagues, and the players who do the ads.  Most of them can&#8217;t speak in complete sentences, and use poor grammar.</p>
<p>The same with companies like Nike, which pays children and slaves in the Far East, pennies per day, and they sell shoes that cost them less than a dollar to make, charging hundreds of dollars just to pay the athletes who wear those shoes.</p>

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>The immoral liberal agitators just keep adding more and more vile practices to their list of &#8220;perfectly acceptable&#8221; things to not only do but be boldly proud in which to participate.</p>
<p>Equal rights:  &#8220;Members of minority groups are sub-human and have no rights.&#8221;<br />
Premarital sex:  &#8220;If it feels good, do it.&#8221;<br />
Abortion:  &#8220;If you don&#8217;t want to keep the baby, just kill it.&#8221;<br />
Divorce:  &#8220;Forget any promises you made and find someone new.&#8221;<br />
Homosexuality:  &#8220;It is your right to love whomever you please.&#8221;<br />
(Note that the Democrat party has embraced all of these at some time.)</p>
<p>Coming soon &#8212;&gt;<br />
Child molesting:  &#8220;No sexual age discrimination against children.&#8221;<br />
Euthanasia:  &#8220;Just give great grandma an injection to stop the nursing home bills.&#8221;<br />
Political cleansing:  &#8220;If someone refuses to live politically correct, they must die.&#8221;<br />
Religious freedom:  &#8220;People who believe in some sort of God must die.&#8221;</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-usafvet even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-414868">

			<div class="comment_avatar">

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>I, for one, just don&#8217;t understand the connections.  It is sports and I thought everyone came to watch SPORTS, not a Church Service, not a Gay Pride Parade, not a Puppet Show, not BLM Movements, just  F-ING sports.  Where does being gay come into it anyway?  Everyone I know is watching to see great plays made ON THE FIELD, and are not worried about how players score off the field.  Can we for once get sports back to just being about sports where every single person is invited to watch without being put down.  I mean really when sports is just sports there is not a single person left out.  Remove politics, remove Religion, remove requirements that you support any one group over any other group and just have sports.  Wow what a simple way to include everyone, and have a very profitable business.  As it is I don&#8217;t care to every watch again and have not checked in on any game or even checked the scores of any game this year, and I have not missed it at all.</p>

				<div id="main-content">

		<div id="content-area" class="clearfix">
			<div class="et_pb_extra_column_main">
																<article id="post-96335" class="module single-post-module post-96335 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-news et-has-post-format-content et_post_format-et-post-format-standard">
														<div class="post-header">
								<h1 class="entry-title">Woke NFL adds National Coming Out Day to its social justice agenda</h1>
								<div class="post-meta vcard">
									<p><a class="url fn" title="Canadian Press" rel="author">Canadian Press</a> | <span class="updated">Oct 16, 2020</span> | <a href="https://www.gopusa.com/category/news/" rel="tag">News</a> | <a class="comments-link" href="https://www.gopusa.com/woke-nfl-adds-national-coming-out-day-to-its-social-justice-agenda/#comments">66 <span title="comment count" class="comment-bubble post-meta-icon"></span></a></p>
								</div>
							</div>
							
														<div class="post-thumbnail header">
								<img src="https://www.gopusa.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/nfl_pride.jpg" alt="Woke NFL adds National Coming Out Day to its social justice agenda" /><p class="caption">Did the NFL miss alienating a few fans?  They're going to fix that right now!</p>							</div>
							
														
							<div class="post-wrap">
															<div class="post-content entry-content">
									<p>NEW YORK — The NFL has launched a series of initiatives associated with LGBTQ History Month, which includes National Coming Out Day on Sunday and Spirit Day on Thursday.</p>
<p>Included are a dedicated website (NFL.com/PRIDE ); a PSA celebrating former NFL players who have come out voicing support; expanded partnerships with GLAAD and The Trevor Project; a pride-themed NFL shield; and an assortment of LGBTQ content airing on NFL Network throughout October.</p>
<p>“The LGBTQ community is an important audience for our sport and a critical part of the NFL family,” said Jonathan Beane, the NFL&#8217;s chief diversity officer. “We continually strive to provide an inclusive and welcoming environment for all.”</p>
<p><iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/XoTylSXO6iU" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe></p>
<p>The PSA that will debut Sunday will feature former NFL players Wade Davis, Ryan O&#8217;Callaghan, Ryan Russell and Jeff Rohrer. Current players Anthony Barr, Calais Campbell, Rob Gronkowski, Anthony Harris, Marlon Humphrey, DeAndre Hopkins, Jarvis Landry and Dalton Risner will offer their support for the LGBTQ community.</p>
<p>In an NFL.com op-ed, Troy Vincent, who overseas league football operations, discusses his commitment to fostering a welcoming and safe environment to active NFL players who are contemplating coming out.</p>
<p>On Thursday, the NFL will join the pledge to “go purple” to support LGBTQ youth in a united stand against bullying.</p>
<p>NFL PRIDE is an employee resource group that aims to heighten the visibility and celebrate members of the LGBTQ community across NFL offices and teams so that employees of all gender identities and sexual orientations can feel comfortable in the workplace. It also helps provide perspective and advises on league initiatives relating to the LGBTQ community and helps administer an advisory working group consisting of players, staff and advocacy partners.</p>
<p>___</p>
<p>More AP NFL coverage: https://apnews.com/NFL and https://twitter.com/AP_NFL</p>
<p>© 2020 The Canadian Press. All rights reserved.</p>
<p>&#8212;-</p>

				<p>Us white straight guys better grab a day before all the good days are gone otherwise we’ll have to settle for Feb 29th.</p>

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>It&#8217;s all politics.  Professional and amateur sports is being ruined by political correctness.  I don&#8217;t even care who wins.  Politics does not belong in professional or amateur sporting events.  I am not amused by these shameless grandstanding prime-donas.  If they want to make a political statement, I am sure the media would gladly give them air time on their networks. </p>
<p>I haven&#8217;t gone to a professional or college game in years.  If I want to watch them, I prefer to do it in the comforts of my home.  At home I can turn them off or not turn them on at all.  At home, I don&#8217;t have to pay those outrageous prices for tickets along with the outrageous cost of hot dogs, popcorn and drinks.</p>

				<p>As long as you don&#8217;t go to the channel you will not be counted.  I know a lot of my friends are having ESPN removed from their service.  I can&#8217;t do that with my provider.  The sports channels are part of my basic package.  If I eliminate the ESPN I also have to eliminate the rest of the basic package.  I&#8217;m stuck with it.  I just have to be careful and make sure I don&#8217;t link up with the sports stations.  As I said, I can turn them off or not turn them on at all.  I chose not to turn them on at all.</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-jimbo999 even depth-2" id="li-comment-415045">
		<article id="comment-415045" class="comment-body clearfix">
			<div class="comment_avatar">
					<img src="https://www.gopusa.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/avatar-default-bubble2-150x150.png" width="80" height="80" alt="Avatar" class="avatar avatar-80wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-80 alignnone photo avatar-default" />			</div>

					<span class="fn">jimbo999</span>				<span class="comment_date">

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>Unfortunately you do pay for the games when you buy something from one or more of their advertisers.  Just think about it when you buy a bottle of flavored water form Coke or Pepsi.  They pay a couple of cents for the can, and a couple of cents for the flavoring and sugar.  The rest of the outrageous cost you paid goes to the TV stations and networks, the sports teams and leagues, and the players who do the ads.  Most of them can&#8217;t speak in complete sentences, and use poor grammar.</p>
<p>The same with companies like Nike, which pays children and slaves in the Far East, pennies per day, and they sell shoes that cost them less than a dollar to make, charging hundreds of dollars just to pay the athletes who wear those shoes.</p>

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>The immoral liberal agitators just keep adding more and more vile practices to their list of &#8220;perfectly acceptable&#8221; things to not only do but be boldly proud in which to participate.</p>
<p>Equal rights:  &#8220;Members of minority groups are sub-human and have no rights.&#8221;<br />
Premarital sex:  &#8220;If it feels good, do it.&#8221;<br />
Abortion:  &#8220;If you don&#8217;t want to keep the baby, just kill it.&#8221;<br />
Divorce:  &#8220;Forget any promises you made and find someone new.&#8221;<br />
Homosexuality:  &#8220;It is your right to love whomever you please.&#8221;<br />
(Note that the Democrat party has embraced all of these at some time.)</p>
<p>Coming soon &#8212;&gt;<br />
Child molesting:  &#8220;No sexual age discrimination against children.&#8221;<br />
Euthanasia:  &#8220;Just give great grandma an injection to stop the nursing home bills.&#8221;<br />
Political cleansing:  &#8220;If someone refuses to live politically correct, they must die.&#8221;<br />
Religious freedom:  &#8220;People who believe in some sort of God must die.&#8221;</p>

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>I, for one, just don&#8217;t understand the connections.  It is sports and I thought everyone came to watch SPORTS, not a Church Service, not a Gay Pride Parade, not a Puppet Show, not BLM Movements, just  F-ING sports.  Where does being gay come into it anyway?  Everyone I know is watching to see great plays made ON THE FIELD, and are not worried about how players score off the field.  Can we for once get sports back to just being about sports where every single person is invited to watch without being put down.  I mean really when sports is just sports there is not a single person left out.  Remove politics, remove Religion, remove requirements that you support any one group over any other group and just have sports.  Wow what a simple way to include everyone, and have a very profitable business.  As it is I don&#8217;t care to every watch again and have not checked in on any game or even checked the scores of any game this year, and I have not missed it at all.</p>

				<div id="main-content">
		<div class="container">
		<div id="content-area" class="clearfix">
			<div class="et_pb_extra_column_main">
																<article id="post-96335" class="module single-post-module post-96335 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-news et-has-post-format-content et_post_format-et-post-format-standard">
														<div class="post-header">
								<h1 class="entry-title">Woke NFL adds National Coming Out Day to its social justice agenda</h1>
								<div class="post-meta vcard">
									<p><a class="url fn" title="Canadian Press" rel="author">Canadian Press</a> | <span class="updated">Oct 16, 2020</span> | <a href="https://www.gopusa.com/category/news/" rel="tag">News</a> | <a class="comments-link" href="https://www.gopusa.com/woke-nfl-adds-national-coming-out-day-to-its-social-justice-agenda/#comments">66 <span title="comment count" class="comment-bubble post-meta-icon"></span></a></p>
								</div>
							</div>
							
														<div class="post-thumbnail header">
								<img src="https://www.gopusa.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/nfl_pride.jpg" alt="Woke NFL adds National Coming Out Day to its social justice agenda" /><p class="caption">Did the NFL miss alienating a few fans?  They're going to fix that right now!</p>							</div>
							
														
							<div class="post-wrap">
															<div class="post-content entry-content">
									<p>NEW YORK — The NFL has launched a series of initiatives associated with LGBTQ History Month, which includes National Coming Out Day on Sunday and Spirit Day on Thursday.</p>
<p>Included are a dedicated website (NFL.com/PRIDE ); a PSA celebrating former NFL players who have come out voicing support; expanded partnerships with GLAAD and The Trevor Project; a pride-themed NFL shield; and an assortment of LGBTQ content airing on NFL Network throughout October.</p>
<p>“The LGBTQ community is an important audience for our sport and a critical part of the NFL family,” said Jonathan Beane, the NFL&#8217;s chief diversity officer. “We continually strive to provide an inclusive and welcoming environment for all.”</p>
<p><iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/XoTylSXO6iU" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe></p>
<p>The PSA that will debut Sunday will feature former NFL players Wade Davis, Ryan O&#8217;Callaghan, Ryan Russell and Jeff Rohrer. Current players Anthony Barr, Calais Campbell, Rob Gronkowski, Anthony Harris, Marlon Humphrey, DeAndre Hopkins, Jarvis Landry and Dalton Risner will offer their support for the LGBTQ community.</p>
<p>In an NFL.com op-ed, Troy Vincent, who overseas league football operations, discusses his commitment to fostering a welcoming and safe environment to active NFL players who are contemplating coming out.</p>
<p>On Thursday, the NFL will join the pledge to “go purple” to support LGBTQ youth in a united stand against bullying.</p>
<p>NFL PRIDE is an employee resource group that aims to heighten the visibility and celebrate members of the LGBTQ community across NFL offices and teams so that employees of all gender identities and sexual orientations can feel comfortable in the workplace. It also helps provide perspective and advises on league initiatives relating to the LGBTQ community and helps administer an advisory working group consisting of players, staff and advocacy partners.</p>
<p>___</p>
<p>More AP NFL coverage: https://apnews.com/NFL and https://twitter.com/AP_NFL</p>
<p>© 2020 The Canadian Press. All rights reserved.</p>
<p>&#8212;-</p>
<p>This content is published through a licensing agreement with <b><a href="http://acquiremedia.com" target="top">Acquire Media</a></b> using its NewsEdge technology.</p>

    <div class="gdrts-inner-wrapper">

				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>They have lost their way. Ratings don&#8217;t seem to matter.<br />
This is just another nail in their coffin! <strong>Who gives a s**t!</strong></p>

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>It&#8217;s all politics.  Professional and amateur sports is being ruined by political correctness.  I don&#8217;t even care who wins.  Politics does not belong in professional or amateur sporting events.  I am not amused by these shameless grandstanding prime-donas.  If they want to make a political statement, I am sure the media would gladly give them air time on their networks. </p>
<p>I haven&#8217;t gone to a professional or college game in years.  If I want to watch them, I prefer to do it in the comforts of my home.  At home I can turn them off or not turn them on at all.  At home, I don&#8217;t have to pay those outrageous prices for tickets along with the outrageous cost of hot dogs, popcorn and drinks.</p>

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>As long as you don&#8217;t go to the channel you will not be counted.  I know a lot of my friends are having ESPN removed from their service.  I can&#8217;t do that with my provider.  The sports channels are part of my basic package.  If I eliminate the ESPN I also have to eliminate the rest of the basic package.  I&#8217;m stuck with it.  I just have to be careful and make sure I don&#8217;t link up with the sports stations.  As I said, I can turn them off or not turn them on at all.  I chose not to turn them on at all.</p>

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>Unfortunately you do pay for the games when you buy something from one or more of their advertisers.  Just think about it when you buy a bottle of flavored water form Coke or Pepsi.  They pay a couple of cents for the can, and a couple of cents for the flavoring and sugar.  The rest of the outrageous cost you paid goes to the TV stations and networks, the sports teams and leagues, and the players who do the ads.  Most of them can&#8217;t speak in complete sentences, and use poor grammar.</p>
<p>The same with companies like Nike, which pays children and slaves in the Far East, pennies per day, and they sell shoes that cost them less than a dollar to make, charging hundreds of dollars just to pay the athletes who wear those shoes.</p>

This leaves only blatant pandering and the fact people want to watch sports, not be preached to about their <strong>theoretical</strong> failings.</p>

				<p>I, for one, just don&#8217;t understand the connections.  It is sports and I thought everyone came to watch SPORTS, not a Church Service, not a Gay Pride Parade, not a Puppet Show, not BLM Movements, just  F-ING sports.  Where does being gay come into it anyway?  Everyone I know is watching to see great plays made ON THE FIELD, and are not worried about how players score off the field.  Can we for once get sports back to just being about sports where every single person is invited to watch without being put down.  I mean really when sports is just sports there is not a single person left out.  Remove politics, remove Religion, remove requirements that you support any one group over any other group and just have sports.  Wow what a simple way to include everyone, and have a very profitable business.  As it is I don&#8217;t care to every watch again and have not checked in on any game or even checked the scores of any game this year, and I have not missed it at all.</p>

				<div id="main-content">
		<div class="container">
		<div id="content-area" class="clearfix">
			<div class="et_pb_extra_column_main">
																<article id="post-96335" class="module single-post-module post-96335 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-news et-has-post-format-content et_post_format-et-post-format-standard">
														<div class="post-header">
								<h1 class="entry-title">Woke NFL adds National Coming Out Day to its social justice agenda</h1>
								<div class="post-meta vcard">
									<p><a class="url fn" title="Canadian Press" rel="author">Canadian Press</a> | <span class="updated">Oct 16, 2020</span> | <a href="https://www.gopusa.com/category/news/" rel="tag">News</a> | <a class="comments-link" href="https://www.gopusa.com/woke-nfl-adds-national-coming-out-day-to-its-social-justice-agenda/#comments">66 <span title="comment count" class="comment-bubble post-meta-icon"></span></a></p>
								</div>
							</div>
							
														<div class="post-thumbnail header">
								<img src="https://www.gopusa.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/nfl_pride.jpg" alt="Woke NFL adds National Coming Out Day to its social justice agenda" /><p class="caption">Did the NFL miss alienating a few fans?  They're going to fix that right now!</p>							</div>
							
														
							<div class="post-wrap">
															<div class="post-content entry-content">
									<p>NEW YORK — The NFL has launched a series of initiatives associated with LGBTQ History Month, which includes National Coming Out Day on Sunday and Spirit Day on Thursday.</p>
<p>Included are a dedicated website (NFL.com/PRIDE ); a PSA celebrating former NFL players who have come out voicing support; expanded partnerships with GLAAD and The Trevor Project; a pride-themed NFL shield; and an assortment of LGBTQ content airing on NFL Network throughout October.</p>
<p>“The LGBTQ community is an important audience for our sport and a critical part of the NFL family,” said Jonathan Beane, the NFL&#8217;s chief diversity officer. “We continually strive to provide an inclusive and welcoming environment for all.”</p>
<p><iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/XoTylSXO6iU" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe></p>
<p>The PSA that will debut Sunday will feature former NFL players Wade Davis, Ryan O&#8217;Callaghan, Ryan Russell and Jeff Rohrer. Current players Anthony Barr, Calais Campbell, Rob Gronkowski, Anthony Harris, Marlon Humphrey, DeAndre Hopkins, Jarvis Landry and Dalton Risner will offer their support for the LGBTQ community.</p>
<p>In an NFL.com op-ed, Troy Vincent, who overseas league football operations, discusses his commitment to fostering a welcoming and safe environment to active NFL players who are contemplating coming out.</p>
<p>On Thursday, the NFL will join the pledge to “go purple” to support LGBTQ youth in a united stand against bullying.</p>
<p>NFL PRIDE is an employee resource group that aims to heighten the visibility and celebrate members of the LGBTQ community across NFL offices and teams so that employees of all gender identities and sexual orientations can feel comfortable in the workplace. It also helps provide perspective and advises on league initiatives relating to the LGBTQ community and helps administer an advisory working group consisting of players, staff and advocacy partners.</p>
<p>___</p>
<p>More AP NFL coverage: https://apnews.com/NFL and https://twitter.com/AP_NFL</p>
<p>© 2020 The Canadian Press. All rights reserved.</p>
<p>&#8212;-</p>
<p>This content is published through a licensing agreement with <b><a href="http://acquiremedia.com" target="top">Acquire Media</a></b> using its NewsEdge technology.</p>

    <div class="gdrts-inner-wrapper">

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>In baseball as in football,,,,The &#8220;Giving a s**t &#8221; part usually comes AFTER the LGBT love making, usually by the cleanup batter after scoring a hit. Bat boys are considered as fair game as well, never a foul ball.</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-nashsevmsn-com odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="li-comment-414788">

			<div class="comment_avatar">
					<img src="https://www.gopusa.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/avatar-default-bubble2-150x150.png" width="80" height="80" alt="Avatar" class="avatar avatar-80wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-80 alignnone photo avatar-default" />			</div>

			<div class="comment_postinfo">

					on 9:30 am October 16, 2020 at 9:30 am				</span>

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>So they will be wearing purple?  Glad to see the Vikings are already dressed for that event.</p>
<p>Actually, this is as dumb as putting billboards up at Disney or commercials in the middle of movies at the theater.  Maybe focus on football and that experience, it is your business.  Companies that push anything outside their core products eventually die.</p>

                Rating: <strong>5.0</strong>/5. From 24 votes.            </div>

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>It&#8217;s all politics.  Professional and amateur sports is being ruined by political correctness.  I don&#8217;t even care who wins.  Politics does not belong in professional or amateur sporting events.  I am not amused by these shameless grandstanding prime-donas.  If they want to make a political statement, I am sure the media would gladly give them air time on their networks. </p>
<p>I haven&#8217;t gone to a professional or college game in years.  If I want to watch them, I prefer to do it in the comforts of my home.  At home I can turn them off or not turn them on at all.  At home, I don&#8217;t have to pay those outrageous prices for tickets along with the outrageous cost of hot dogs, popcorn and drinks.</p>

		<article id="comment-414900" class="comment-body clearfix">
			<div class="comment_avatar">
					<img src="https://www.gopusa.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/coralbuster-150x150.jpg" width="80" height="80" alt="ltuser" class="avatar avatar-80 wp-user-avatar wp-user-avatar-80 alignnone photo" />			</div>

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>I&#8217;d LOVE To see how many cable providers are being inundated with folks CANCELLING their sports network packages.</p>

			<div class="comment_area">
				
				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>As long as you don&#8217;t go to the channel you will not be counted.  I know a lot of my friends are having ESPN removed from their service.  I can&#8217;t do that with my provider.  The sports channels are part of my basic package.  If I eliminate the ESPN I also have to eliminate the rest of the basic package.  I&#8217;m stuck with it.  I just have to be careful and make sure I don&#8217;t link up with the sports stations.  As I said, I can turn them off or not turn them on at all.  I chose not to turn them on at all.</p>

				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>Unfortunately you do pay for the games when you buy something from one or more of their advertisers.  Just think about it when you buy a bottle of flavored water form Coke or Pepsi.  They pay a couple of cents for the can, and a couple of cents for the flavoring and sugar.  The rest of the outrageous cost you paid goes to the TV stations and networks, the sports teams and leagues, and the players who do the ads.  Most of them can&#8217;t speak in complete sentences, and use poor grammar.</p>
<p>The same with companies like Nike, which pays children and slaves in the Far East, pennies per day, and they sell shoes that cost them less than a dollar to make, charging hundreds of dollars just to pay the athletes who wear those shoes.</p>

				<div class="comment-content clearfix">
				<p>I think this one will backfire on the 70% black player populated NFL sport. I&#8217;ve played  and competed in a lot of sports in my day and found that black men take much more pride in their manhood and are way more offended by gay men than whites are.</p>

Wow what a simple way to include everyone, and have a very profitable business.             //$( document ).ajaxStart(function() {

				if ($(this).attr("method") != "get") { $(this).append('<input type="hidden" name="fs_ErxjBJVMuwv" value="Qf3nMFucxh7Uad" />'); }

                return true;
            });

			
            jQuery.ajaxSetup({
                beforeSend: function (e, data) {

                    //console.log(Object.getOwnPropertyNames(data).sort());
                    //console.log(data.type);

                    if (data.type !== 'POST') return;

                    if (typeof data.data === 'object' && data.data !== null) {
						data.data.append("fs_ErxjBJVMuwv", "Qf3nMFucxh7Uad");

                }
            });

        });
